articles.headline: The Power Balance Is Shifting in London’s Commercial Real Estate
articles.snippet: An extended winter lockdown has shaken the usual arrangement between landlords and tenants ahead of a government review of leasing legislation.
articles.abstract: An extended winter lockdown has shaken the usual arrangement between landlords and tenants ahead of a government review of leasing legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For years, landlords have had the upper hand in London’s real estate market, pushing up rents as businesses clamored for prime locations near offices, tourism hot spots and transport hubs and as the city’s population grew and grew. Restaurants were often locked into leases with clauses that allowed the rent to only go up. Retailers faced increasingly exorbitant rents.

articles.headline: Do Fed Policies Fuel Bubbles? Some See GameStop as a Red Flag
articles.snippet: Analysts warn that low-interest rates are promoting speculative bubbles. The Fed itself has downplayed the possibility that it’s behind asset prices.
articles.abstract: Analysts warn that low-interest rates are promoting speculative bubbles. The Fed itself has downplayed the possibility that it’s behind asset prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before it fueled the run-up in GameStop’s stock, WallStreetBets, the Reddit message board, had another claim to fame: It helped popularize a series of memes centered on the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, and his central bank’s policy of keeping interest rates near rock bottom while buying government bonds to bolster the economy.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Senate Agrees Trial Is Constitutional, as Trump Consolidates Votes for an Acquittal
articles.snippet: After a day that featured a harrowing video of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, only six Republicans joined Democrats in agreeing to allow the trial to proceed, signaling there was not enough support for a conviction.
articles.abstract: After a day that featured a harrowing video of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, only six Republicans joined Democrats in agreeing to allow the trial to proceed, signaling there was not enough support for a conviction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided Senate voted on Tuesday to proceed with Donald J. Trump’s second impeachment trial, narrowly rejecting constitutional objections after House prosecutors opened their case with a harrowing 13-minute video capturing the deadly Capitol riot he stands accused of inciting.

articles.headline: ‘Dad, I Don’t Want to Come Back to the Capitol’: Raskin Speaks of the Horror of Jan. 6
articles.snippet: Representative Jamie Raskin, the Maryland Democrat who is the lead prosecutor in the second impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump, choked back tears in his presentation on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Representative Jamie Raskin, the Maryland Democrat who is the lead prosecutor in the second impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump, choked back tears in his presentation on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The speech, delivered before a rapt Senate chamber on Tuesday, will be remembered at the Capitol, probably for a long time, for its appeal to the still-raw emotions after the mob attack on the jurors’ workplace and courtroom.
articles.byline: By Mark Leibovich and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: The First Trial Seemed Abstract. This One Is a Visceral Reckoning Over Trump.
articles.snippet: At issue will be many aspects that defined Donald Trump’s presidency: his relentless assaults on truth, his fomenting of divisions, his shattering of norms and his undermining of an election.
articles.abstract: At issue will be many aspects that defined Donald Trump’s presidency: his relentless assaults on truth, his fomenting of divisions, his shattering of norms and his undermining of an election.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was no phone call transcript, no dry words on a page open to interpretation. This was a horde of extremists pushing over barricades and beating police officers. This was a mob smashing windows and pounding on doors. This was a mass of marauders setting up a gallows and shouting, “Take the building!” and “Fight for Trump!”

articles.headline: Wall Street’s New Favorite Deal Trend Has Issues
articles.snippet: Known as SPACs, these shell companies allow businesses to sell shares to the public with different disclosure than usual. What could go wrong?
articles.abstract: Known as SPACs, these shell companies allow businesses to sell shares to the public with different disclosure than usual. What could go wrong?
articles.lead_paragraph: In Wall Street’s usually brash way, a new saying is making the rounds. It isn’t in good taste, but it speaks to a phenomenon that is transforming finance and corporate America.

articles.headline: ‘I Did Something Useful’: Unemployed Workers Take On the Virus in Temp Jobs
articles.snippet: Some workers in devastated industries in Britain are finding solace and using their old skills as coronavirus testers, contact-tracing callers and hospital housekeeping workers.
articles.abstract: Some workers in devastated industries in Britain are finding solace and using their old skills as coronavirus testers, contact-tracing callers and hospital housekeeping workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Georgia Paget was an assistant stage manager at London’s production of “Hamilton.” David Lawrence was directing choruses and orchestras throughout Britain. Katy Oakden, a onetime equine midwife, was managing a busy veterinary practice. Mark Karrie, a sound engineer, had just begun a national tour for a West End musical.

articles.headline: With Vaccines in More Drugstores, Pharmacies Go on Hiring Sprees
articles.snippet: Pharmacies are dangling five-figure signing bonuses and competing against one another to quickly recruit pharmacists and support staff.
articles.abstract: Pharmacies are dangling five-figure signing bonuses and competing against one another to quickly recruit pharmacists and support staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: Phones are ringing with plentiful job opportunities. Prospective employers are dangling five-figure signing bonuses. Businesses are hounding universities for potential recruits.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Profits From Trucks and S.U.V.s Fuel Its Electric Quest
articles.snippet: The automaker earned more than $6 billion last year — money that it will plow into the development of electric and autonomous vehicles.
articles.abstract: The automaker earned more than $6 billion last year — money that it will plow into the development of electric and autonomous vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a pandemic that shuttered auto factories for nearly two months and sent car sales tumbling, General Motors made more than $6 billion last year, one of its highest profit totals ever.

articles.headline: How Right-Wing Radio Stoked Anger Before the Capitol Siege
articles.snippet: Shows hosted by Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity and other talk radio stars promoted debunked claims of a stolen election and urged listeners to “fight back.”
articles.abstract: Shows hosted by Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity and other talk radio stars promoted debunked claims of a stolen election and urged listeners to “fight back.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days before a mob of Trump supporters invaded the United States Capitol, upending the nation’s peaceful transition of power and leaving at least five people dead, the right-wing radio star Glenn Beck delivered a message to his flock of 10.5 million listeners: “It is time to fight.”
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Tiffany Hsu, Katie Robertson and Keith Collins
